instruction: What were the results of comparing the deep learning model based on one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D CNN) with five traditional classification models in the detection and recognition of pesticide residues on garlic chive leaves using short wave infrared hyperspectral images?
Output:

- The accuracy rates of the 1D CNN on the train set, develop set, and test set were 98.5%, 98.0%, and 97.9%, respectively.

instruction: Can the combination of hyperspectral imaging technology and deep learning be used as a superior method for non-destructive detection and recognition of pesticide residues on garlic chive leaves, as compared to traditional classification models?
Output: Yes, the combination of hyperspectral imaging technology and deep learning can be used as a superior method for non-destructive detection and recognition of pesticide residues on garlic chive leaves, as compared to traditional classification models. The study used a deep learning model based on one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D CNN) to recognize pesticide residues on garlic chive leaves. The results showed that the accuracy rates of the 1D CNN model were excellent, with accuracy rates of 98.5%, 98.0%, and 97.9% on the train set, develop set, and test set, respectively. Additionally, the areas under the receiver operating characteristic curves for the four classes were all greater than 0.99, indicating the excellent accuracy and robustness of the deep learning model. In comparison, the deep learning model outperformed traditional classification models such as k-nearest neighbors, linear discriminant analysis, naive Bayes, random forest, and support vector machine. Therefore, the combination of hyperspectral imaging technology and deep learning has great potential for the non-destructive detection and recognition of pesticide residues on garlic chive leaves.
